review.title: Discovering Semantic Spatial and Spatio-Temporal Outliers from Moving Object Trajectories
review.abstract: Several algorithms have been proposed for discovering patterns from trajectories of moving objects, but only a few have concentrated on outlier detection. Existing approaches, in general, discover spatial outliers, and do not provide any further analysis of the patterns. In this paper we introduce semantic spatial and spatio-temporal outliers and propose a new algorithm for trajectory outlier detection. Semantic outliers are computed between regions of interest, where objects have similar movement intention, and there exist standard paths which connect the regions. We show with experiments on real data that the method finds semantic outliers from trajectory data that are not discovered by similar approaches.

metadata.title: Discovering Semantic Spatial and Spatio-Temporal Outliers from Moving Object Trajectories

sections.text: ar Xiv: 130 3.51 32v1 [cs.ASeveral algorithms have been proposed for detecting patterns from the trajectories of moving objects, but only a few have focused on detecting outliers. Existing approaches generally detect spatial outliers and do not provide further analysis of the patterns. In this paper, we introduce semantic spatial and spatio-temporal outliers and propose a new algorithm for detecting outliers. Semantic outliers are calculated between interesting regions where objects have similar intentions of movement, and there are standard paths that connect the regions. We show with experiments on real data that the method finds semantic outliers from trajectory data that are not detected by similar approaches.

sections.heading: 3 Mining Semantic Outliers from Trajectories
sections.text: In this section, the definitions and an algorithm are introduced to find semantic outliers from trajectories.

sections.heading: 3.1 Main Concepts
sections.text: Before defining the trajectories semantic outliers, we introduce some basic definitions, starting with the points > 1 (point) A point p is a tuple (x, y, t) where x and y are spatial coordinates and t is the time in which the coordinates are collected.A list of points arranged in time is a trajectory 2 (trajectory).Trajectory T is a list of points < p1, p2, p3, pn > where the intentions (i, yi, ti) and t1 < t2 < t3 < t3 < t3 < t3 < tn.Usually the patterns do not hold for the entire trajectory or during full trajectory life. Trajector patterns occur in a part of the trajectory patterns, and this is especially true for the outliers.

sections.heading: 3.2 TRA-SOD: an Algorithm for Mining Trajectory Semantic Outliers
sections.text: This year it is more than ever before in the history of the city.

sections.heading: 4 Experimental Results
sections.text: In this section we present the results of two experiments with real trajectory data sets, compare the results of our method with TRAOD [8] and perform a parameter analysis. Both data sets are trajectories of people. The first data set is trajectories of cars in the city of Porto Alegre, Brazil, and the second represents trajectories of pedestrians in the city of Amsterdam.

sections.heading: 4.1 Experiment 1: Car Trajectories in the City of Porto Alegre
sections.text: This experiment was carried out on a dataset of 241 trajectories, with a set of 197959 points given, with an average sampling rate of points every second. Figure 7 shows this dataset over a map of urban districts. This experiment was carried out by considering 50 meters as maxDist, so that trajectories moving in the same street should be considered neighbors following the same path. Minimum support for minSup was set to 4, indicating that candidates will be standards if they have at least 4 candidates in their neighborhood. In this experiment, we considered time tolerance of 30 minutes, as the dataset does not have many synchronized trajectories leaving the regions at a similar time. Regions considered in this experiment were densely populated areas in different districts of Porto Alegre. Figure 8 shows the result between the districts of Partenon (called Region A) and Jardim Botanico (called Region B), with Figure 1 being abbreviated as Figure 1.

sections.heading: 4.1.1 Analyzing the Meaning of Outliers and Standards
sections.text: Table 1 presents part of the production of the TRA-SOD algorithm, where the O3 and O4 are the outliers between regions A and B, and the others are the outliers between B and A. Several features about the outliers and the standards are presented. The first part of the table shows that the length of the outliers is greater than the average length of the standards (Avg Length). The time of grandeur provides more information about the outliers. O3 and O4, which move from A to B, occur on Tuesday.

sections.heading: 4.1.2 Comparing the algorithms TRAOD and TRA-SOD
sections.text: In this section we compare the output of the TRAOD [8] and TRASOD algorithms. This comparison is performed to show that both methods have different patterns, which is mainly obvious because the proposals are different. TRAOD does not consider regions and does not perform further analyses of outliers as TRA-SOD, but to compare the results of both algorithms, which we consider to be input for both methods. TRAOD algorithm has as input the maximum distance between the trajector partitions (D), the maximum proportion of trajectories (p) for the non-outliers, and the proportion of partitions (f) that should be an output.

sections.heading: 4.2 Experiment 2: Trajectories of Pedestrians in the City of Amsterdam
sections.text: This experiment was carried out using the trajectory data of a mobile learning game developed by the Waag Society [27] in Amsterdam, with pupils aged between 11 and 12 years. Students were divided into 7 groups, with the aim of solving a puzzle. Each pupil was given a GPS that collected his trajectory. This data set is in Figure 14. This data set has 466 trajectories that summarize 62264 points, with aleatory sampling rates. For this experiment, we considered 4 high density regions. A total of 66 candidates (subtrajectories that move between regions) were calculated and are in Figure 15. The following pairs of regions generated candidates: A to B, B to C, B to D, B to A, C to B and D to B. TRA-SOD was carried out taking into account two different parameters. In both experiments, we considered maxDist = 50 meters, which is the most suitable value for the group, the objects that move in the same street and avoid moving parallel roads.

sections.heading: 4.2.1 Case 1
sections.text: For this reason, it is interesting to see that there is a standard route leading from A to B, while regions B and D have 2 standard routes. In Figure 16 (b), we can see that outliers are sparsely represented in the city. In Figure 2, the distribution of outliers and standards between regions is shown.

sections.heading: 4.2.2 Case 2
sections.text: A second experiment with minSup = 6 yielded a total of 19 standards and 11 outliers, as in Table 4 and Figure 19. With an increase in minSup, more candidates are needed to find the standard route, which of course led to a reduction in the number of standards. This is possible because of the 5 standard routes found in Case 1, only 2 were found in Case 2: from B to A and from B to D. Table 4 shows the totality of standards and outliers between these regions. From B to A, 3 standards and 7 outliers were discovered. This is possible because of the 10 candidates, only 3 standards crossed the most direct route, as in Figure 19. From B to D, a row of 16 standards and 4 outliers was found, which means that most candidates moved together by the same route. From B to A and from B to D, the number of outliers increased when compared with the result of Case 1, with a lower minimum velocity of the Olier than the Olier. Table 5 shows the details of the outliers, 31, 44, 30, 31, 28, 31, 31, 31, 31, 31, 31, 31, 31, 31, 31, 31, 31, 31, 31, 31, 31, 31, 31, 31, 31, 31, 31, 31 and 24.

sections.heading: 4.2.3 Comparing TRAOD and TRA-SOD
sections.text: Since the experiments with TRAOD were carried out using the authors "algorithm (downloaded from [26]), we did not edit the resulting image to add the regions to the mapping, since TRAOD does not consider regions. TRAOD transforms subtrajectories into lines, which makes the result slightly different from TRA-SOD. TRAOD found a total of 36 outliers among the candidates, while TRA-SOD 28 and 14. TRAOD does not look for a standard path to find outliers, and does not perform any further analysis, so it is impossible to determine the direction of the outliers found by TRAOD whether they leave or return, and whether they are synchronized or occurred at a similar time period, as time is not taken into account.

sections.heading: 4.3 TRA-SOD Parameter Analysis
sections.text: As every year, and this year too, the number of visitors to the USA is many times higher than in other countries.

sections.heading: 4.4 Conclusion and Future Works
sections.text: Several algorithms have been proposed for trajectory data retrieval, but few consider trajectory outliers detection and pattern interpretation.Existing approaches to trajectory outliers mainly take into account the spatial dimension, and time was not the focus. They do not do a deeper analysis of discovered patterns to give more meaning or semantics. In fact, existing trajectory outliers look for detours across the entire data set. In this paper, we look for outliers among trajectories that have similar goals, i.e., trajectories that move between the same regions. We present the definition of semantic outliers and an algorithm to find such patterns from trajectories, taking into account both spatial and spatial-temporal information. Semantic outliers are those trajectories that move between regions of interest and that follow a path that connects the regions.

As the experiments with TRAOD were done with the algorithm of the authors (downloaded from [26]), we did not edit the resulted image to add the regions to the figure, since TRAOD does not consider regions.

Existing approaches, in general, discover spatial outliers, and do not provide any further analysis of the patterns. In this paper we introduce semantic spatial and spatio-temporal outliers and propose a new algorithm for trajectory outlier detection. Semantic outliers are computed between regions of interest, where objects have similar movement intention, and there exist standard paths which connect the regions.
